Preventative Health Screens: 
 TOBACCO EDUCATION AND SCREENING: 
 Quitting tobacco, or never starting, is the most important thing you can do to 
protect your health now and in the future. 
 Cutting down on tobacco while you are ill is not enough. 
 Occasional or light tobacco use is still dangerous. 
 Some of the health risks of tobacco use include: 
 - Lung cancer, and other cancers 
 - Heart disease, high blood pressure, and heart attack 
 - Stroke 
 - Vascular disease 
 - Breathing problems (coughing, wheezing, and shortness of  breath) 
 - Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) such as  Asthma or Emphysema 
 - Infertility in women 

 The benefits of not using tobacco include: 
 - Lower risk for lung and other types of cancer. 
 - Reduces the risk for coronary heart disease, high blood pressure, heart 
attack, stroke, and peripheral vascular disease. 
 - For those who quit using tobacco, the risk of coronary heart disease risk is 
reduced within 1 to 2 years of quitting. 
- Reduces respiratory symptoms, such as coughing, wheezing, and shortness of 
breath. The rate of decline in lung function is slower among persons who quit 
using Tobacco. 
 - Reduces the risk of developing chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), 
one of the leading causes of death in the United States. 
 - Women who quit using tobacco during their reproductive years  reduce the risk 
for infertility. Women who stop Tobacco  during pregnancy also reduce their risk 
of having a low  birth weight baby. 
 - Cost savings! Tobacco use is expensive. 

 Source: http://www.cdc.gov/tobacco 
 If you use tobacco and decide to quit, we recommend you take  these steps: 
 1. Set a quit date; ideally the quit date should be within 2 weeks. 
 2. Identify the reasons for, and benefits of quitting; 
 3. Remove all tobacco products from home and work settings; 
 4. Identify and plan ahead for challenges to quitting; 
 5. Get support from family, friends, and co-workers; 
 6. And remember - You can do this!!! 

 Resources for Tobacco users: 
 - Colorado QuitLine:  To contact the QuitLine, call 1-800-QUIT-NOW  (1-800-784-
8669) or visit www.coquitline.org. 
 - Would you like a referral to tobacco cessation classes or  therapy? 
 
The VA offers this service to you! Please ask any of our health care providers 
to assist you in getting enrolled. 
 - Would you like medications to help you quit tobacco? 

There are smoking cessation medications and nicotine  patches that can assist 
you meet your goal to quit tobacco. 

The VA also offers this service to you! Please ask any of our health care 
providers to assist you in getting a prescription. 

Six Patient is a past tobacco user - quit 2002
